Mandarin peels 860 790 40 0.05 50 [60] Tea bag 712 500 50 0.1 68 [61] glucosamine 1194 505 100 0.1 50 [62] Rice husk 934 355 100 0.2 42 [63] Shrimp shell 549 450 100 0.3 63 [25] Corncob 1600 554 50 0.1 44 [64] Bamboo ∼750 ∼500 50 0.1 60 [65] Goat hair 921 489 300 0.2 54 This work Sulfur-encapsulated in heteroatom-doped hierarchical porous carbon derived from goat hair for high performance lithium–sulfur batteries Juan Ren Yibei Zhou Huali Wu Fengyu Xie Chenggang Xu ⁎ Dunmin Lin ⁎ College of Chemistry and Materials Science, Sichuan Normal University, Chengdu 610066, Sichuan, China College of Chemistry and Materials Science Sichuan Normal University Chengdu 610066 China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Biomass-derived carbon materials have aroused widespread concern as host material of sulfur to enhance electrochemical performances for lithium–sulfur batteries. Herein, goat hair, as a low-cost and eco-friendly precursor, is employed to fabricate cauliflower-like in-situ nitrogen, oxygen and phosphorus tri-doped porous biomass carbon (NOPC) by a facile activation with H3PO4 and carbonization process. The morphology and microstructure of NOPC can be readily tuned by altering pyrolysis temperature. The as-prepared NOPC matrix material carbonized at 600 °C possesses 3D hierarchical porous structure, high specific surface area (535.352 m2 g−1), and appropriate pore size and pore size distribution. Encapsulating sulfur into the NOPC depends on a stem-melting technology as cathode materials of Li–S batteries. Due to the synergistic effect of special physical structure and inherent tri-doping of N, O and P, electrons and ions transfer and utilization of active sulfur in the materials are improved, and the shuttle behaviors of soluble lithium polysulfides are also mitigated. Consequently, the S/NOPC-600 composite exhibits excellent electrochemical performance, giving a high initial discharge capacity of 1185 mA h g−1 at 0.05 C and maintaining a relatively considerable capacity of 489 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C after 300 cycles. Our work shows that a promising candidate for cathode material of Li–S batteries can be synthesized using low-cost and renewable biomass materials by a facile process. Graphical abstract Goat hair, as a low-cost, eco-friendly and renewable precursor, is employed to fabricate cauliflower-like in-situ nitrogen, oxygen and phosphorus tri-doped porous biomass carbon (NOPC-600) by a facile activation with H3PO4 and carbonization process. The related S/NOPC-600 composite was fabricated by a stem-melting technology as cathode materials of lithium–sulfur batteries and exhibits excellent electrochemical performance. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biomass-derived carbon materials Goat hair Nitrogen Oxygen and phosphorus tri-doping Lithium sulfur batteries 1 Introduction With ever-increasing energy storage requirements of portable electric devices and electric vehicles, exploiting sustainable energy storage system with high energy density and long service life has become an unavoidable hot topic [1,2]. Conventional commercial rechargeable lithium-ion batteries, as the most widely applied battery devices in various fields (e.g., smart phones, laptops, electric tools), no longer meet insatiable demands for energy storages owing to their limited theoretical energy density [3,4]. Lithium–sulfur batteries (Li–S) with ultrahigh theoretical energy density (2600 W h kg−1) and specific capacity (1675 mA h g−1) have obtained extensive attention to serve as one of the most attractive candidates for next generation high energy density battery systems. Furthermore, sulfur has lots of distinct advantages, including low cost, non-poison and environmental friendliness, which make it an excellent cathode material [5–7]. However, to date, the commercialization application of Li–S batteries is still hampered by several severe obstacles, such as low sulfur utilization, fast capacity decay with cycling and poor coulombic efficiency. These issues mainly originate from (1) the electronic insulating property of both sulfur (5 × 10−30 S cm−1 at 25 °C) and insoluble end reduction products of Li2S/Li2S2, (2) the high solubility of long-chain lithium polysulfides (Li2S x , 4 ≤ x ≤ 8) intermediates in organic electrolyte, and (3) significant volumetric expansion of ∼80% upon complete lithiation during charging/discharging process. Therefore, extensive researches have been made to improve electrochemical performance by confining sulfur into a conductive materials (porous carbon [8], conductive polymer [9,10], metal oxides/sulfides [11,12] and MOFs [13,14]), developing a novel electrolyte (solid-state [15], polymer [16] and ionic liquid electrolytes [17]), modifying the separator (carbon species [18,19], polymeric [20] and inorganic [21]) and protecting lithium anode (P2S5 [22], graphite film [23] and Al2O3 [24]). Among these strategies, incorporating active sulfur into carbon frameworks with good electrical conductivity and diverse nanostructures, such as micro/meso‑porous carbon [25,26], carbon nanotubes/spheres [8,27,28], graphene [29,30] and graphene oxides [31,32], have been regarded as one of the most effective strategies to enhance the electrochemical performance of lithium sulfur batteries. Nevertheless, the capacity fading cannot be avoided over a long cycle process, which is ascribed to the weak physical adsorbing between nonpolar porous carbon and highly polar polysulfides [33]. Recently, it has been frequently reported that heteroatom-doped carbonaceous material with porous structures is a most promising candidate for cathode material of lithium sulfur batteries due to its high surface area, tuned pore size and superior chemical stability [25,34]. Importantly, strong chemical bonds can be formed between lithium polysulfides and heteroatoms in carbon hosts [29,33]. Various heteroatom (e.g., N [25,33,35], O [36], P [37] and S [38,39]) groups have been introduced into carbon-based materials and exhibit strong chemical adsorption to polysulfides; as a result, cycling stability and discharge capacity of the batteries are significantly enhanced because of the retarding dissolution of polysulfides. Up to now, a variety of heteroatom-doped porous carbon materials, such as N-doped hierarchical porous carbon [29,30], O-doped carbon nanotubes [40], and S-doped graphene [39], have been developed and used to prepare C/S composites for addressing the above mentioned issues. In these composites, sulfur is encapsulated into nanopores of carbonaceous materials, which immensely increases the connection between insulated active sulfur and conductivity substrate, and thus enhances the utilization of active material. In addition, the dissolution of lithium polysulfides intermediates may be effectively inhibited by the synergistic entrapping effect of heteroatom and porous microstructure. For example, Zhang et al. have fabricated a 3D porous N, O co-doped structure based on 1D self-weaving CNTs and 2D modified graphene by a one-pot pyrolysis process. This unique structure of open, porous and heteroatoms doped 3D network not only enables rapid Li+/e− transfer in conductive network, but also prevents the re-stacking of graphene and the dissolution of lithium polysulfides intermediates during charging/discharging process; as a consequence, a superior discharge capacity of 1373.8 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C is exhibited in this cathode [41]. In general, the afore-mentioned heteroatom-doped carbons are synthesized by a relatively sophisticated process or using poisonous and/or high-cost chemical reagents, which restrict their scale-up production and practical application [42]. Recently, the inherent heteroatom-doped porous biomass-derived carbon materials, such as shrimp shell [25], rice husk [43], mushroom [44], egg white [45], banana peel [46] and pig nails [47], have appealed interest owing to their easy availability and low cost. Among biomass materials, goat hair, as a kind of eco-friendly, low-cost, easy available and sustainable biomass material, is widely distributed around the world; and it consists of abundant crude protein (keratin) and amino acid. These suggest that goat hair should be a promising carbon source to produce intrinsic heteroatom-doped porous carbon material and may be widely applied in energy storage, catalysis, adsorption etc. Herein, the in-situ nitrogen, oxygen and phosphorus trip-doped hierarchical porous carbon (NOPC) derived from goat hair was fabricated by a simple H3PO4 activation and high temperature carbonization method, and employed to construct the S/NOPC composite by stem-melting technology. Compared with the representative synthesis routes (e.g., pyrolysis of polymeric [48], CVD [49,50], template method [51]) to prepare the porous carbon, this method is relative facile, safe, inexpensive and eco-friendly. More importantly, the activated precursor was thermal treatment at 600 °C (NOPC-600) with a high product yield (31.2%) that is conductive to large-scale production carbon material. When the S/NOPC-600 was employed as the cathode in Li–S batteries, a good specific capacity and cycling stability were obtained. The enhancement of the electrochemical performance is mainly imputed to the synergetic effect of the inherent N, O and P heteroatoms homogeneous doping and special physical structure of the host material (NOPC-600); and the matched morphology, microstructure and electrochemical properties of materials were investigated in detail. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of NOPC All chemical reagents used in this work were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd, and the goat hair was available from local farm (Chengdu, China). Typically, 10 g raw material of goat hair was cleaned with distilled water several times, dried at 80 °C for 24 h and cut into small segments with the length of 0.5 cm. After that, the material was impregnated with H3PO4 solution (the volume ratio of H3PO4 to H2O = 4:6) and dissolved by heating at 150 °C in an oil bath. Meanwhile, the superfluous water was evaporated in this process. The dissolved mixture was calcinated for 2 h at 550, 600 and 650 °C, respectively, in a N2 flowing in a tube furnace. The carbonized materials were thoroughly washed with ethanol and copious distilled water until the pH value is ∼7. Finally, the samples were dried at 150 °C for 24 h in a vacuum oven. The obtained goat hair-derived carbons at the different calcinated temperatures of 550, 600 and 650 °C were labeled as NOPC-550, NOPC-600 and NOPC-650, respectively. 2.2 Fabrication of S/NOPC composites The S/NOPC composites were fabricated by a classical stem-melting technology. Sulfur was encapsulated into the porous carbon matrixes via a two-step method: (1) four alundum crucibles with different sizes were inter-lapped each other, NOPC was placed in the smallest crucible, adequate sulfur was put between the crucibles, and the apparatus was heated at 115 °C for 24 h in a vacuum oven, which is intended to create a sulfur atmosphere for the NOPC; and (2) the NOPC was mixed well with the sublimed sulfur at a weight ratio of 1:1 by grinding for 0.5 h in an agate mortar; and the mixture was heated at 155 °C for 24 h in an electric heat oven. The obtained carbon/sulfur composites were labeled as S/NOPC-550, S/NOPC-600 and S/NOPC-6500, respectively. 2.3 Material characterizations The crystalline structure of the obtained materials were detected via X-ray diffraction analysis with Cu Kα (λ = 1.540598 Å) radiation (XRD, Smart Lab, Rigaku, Japan) at a scan rate of 4°/min−1 from 10° to 80° at room temperature. The morphologies and microstructures of the samples were observed using the field-emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM, JSM-7500, JEOL, Japan) and transmission electron microscope (FE-TEM, GZF20, JEOL, Japan). The specific surface areas and pore size distribution of the as-synthesized samples were measured via physical adsorption at 77 K (BET, ASAP2020, Micromeritics, USA) in accordance with the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms. The content of sulfur in the composites were investigated using a thermoanalyzer (DSC-TGA, Q500, TA, USA) under a N2 atmosphere at the temperature range of room temperature to 600 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy spectra of the composites were conducted using a PHI 5000VersaProbe XPS instrument (XPS, ESCALAB 250XI, Thermo Fisher, USA) with monochromatic Al-Kα radiation at room temperature. 2.4 Electrochemical measurement To evaluate electrochemical characterization of the S/NOPC materials, all electrodes were fabricated by blending S/NOPC composite materials (80 wt%), acetylene black (Super P, 10 wt%) and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF, 10 wt%) binder in N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP) solvent. The mixed slurry was stirred for 3 h in a magnetic apparatus, then casted onto current collector (aluminum foil) and dried at 60 °C for 24 h in a vacuum oven. After that, the film was punched into the wafers with a diameter of 14 mm. The active material loading of sulfur cathode is ∼1.3 mg cm−2. CR2032-type coin cells were assembled by employing S/NOPC composite as cathode, Li as anode, Celgard 2400 as membrane, and sealed in an argon-filled glove box (MB-Labstar, Germany). The electrolyte was a mixture solution of 1.0 M lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) dissolved in 1,3-dioxolane (DOL) and 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) (v/v, 1:1) containing 1 wt% LiNO3 as the additive. Galvanostatic charge/discharge tests were carried out between 1.7 and 3.0 V to examine the discharge capacity and cycle life of batteries at various rates (1 C = 1675 mA g−1) at room temperature with test instruments (LAND, CT2001A, China). Cyclic voltammetry (CV, 0.1 mV s−1, 1.5–3.0 V) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS, 100 kHz–10 mHz) were conducted using an electrochemical workstation (CHI660E, China). 3 Results and discussion Goat hair, as a sustainable biomass material containing abundant protein and amino acid, can be easily available in the world, which is beneficial to constructing heteroatom-doped porous carbon matrix in a large-scale production. The entire synthesis process of S/NOPC composites is illustrated in Fig. 1 . The goat hair was firstly cleaned, dried and sheared into segments, and then activated by a H3PO4 solution. After that, the activated mixture was carbonized at various temperatures (550, 600 and 650 °C) under a N2 atmosphere, and cauliflower-like porous biomass carbon was obtained. Finally, sulfur was incorporated into porous carbon by a conventional melt-diffusion method. The microstructures and morphologies of the as-obtained NOPC and the related S/NOPC composites are displayed in Fig. 2 . At low carbonized temperature of 550 °C, the NOPC-550 shows a slightly tight block-like structure with different size gap among blocks (Fig. 2a1). When sulfur is mixed with the NOPC-550, sulfur cannot be completely embedded into the carbon material and a part of sulfur aggregates and exposes on the surface of NOPC-550. Therefore, as seen in Fig. 2(a2), a relatively dense morphology is observed for the prepared S/NOPC-550 composite. Unlike the NOPC-550, the NOPC-600 carbonized at 600 °C exhibits a 3D cauliflower-like loose structure and the homogeneous nanoparticles are distributed in the materials (Fig. 2b1), which is beneficial to encapsulating sulfur and anchoring polysulfides during charging/discharging. After sulfur is loaded into the NOPC-600 (Fig. 2b2), the original cauliflower-like structure is well maintained and evident sulfur particles cannot be found on the surface of the carbon/sulfur composite, which suggests that sulfur has been effectively encapsulated into the fluffy carbon structure by capillary force. However, excessive temperature is not conducive to the creation of loose and porous structure. At high temperature of 650 °C, the material exhibits a compact and hardened structure with smooth surface and few nanopores (Fig. 2c1). Since there are not enough pores in the NOPC-650, active sulfur cannot be trapped well so that many agglomerated sulfur particles appear on the surface of S/NOPC-650 (Fig. 2c2). Obviously, carbonized temperature has a significant influence on the microstructures and morphologies of the materials. The optimum carbonized temperature is 600 °C, where the goat hair-derived hierarchical porous carbon material can be obtained. Therefore, the NOPC-600 is expected as an excellent carbon matrix to incorporate sulfur and enhance the electrochemical performance of Li–S batteries. The TEM images of NOPC-600 and S/NOPC-600 are shown in Fig. 3 . The disordered hierarchical porous and loose structure can be observed in the NOPC-600 from the low magnification TEM (Fig. 3a1). From the high magnification TEM (Fig. 3a2), great quantities of white spots are exhibited on the disordered carbon, implying that plentiful micropores/mesopores exist in the NOPC-600, which should be ascribed to chemical etching induced by H3PO4 on goat hair. The unique porous structure of NOPC-600 not only can increase rapid transfer channels for electrons/ions, but also supply enough space to accommodate sulfur and anchor soluble polysulfides, which is important to induce the outstanding electrochemical performance in Li–S batteries. As seen from Fig. 3(b1, b2), the fabricated S/NOPC-600 composite displays a parallel morphology to the original porous carbon material. Compared with the NOPC-600, only a small number of white spots can be observed in the S/NOPC-600, manifesting that sublimed sulfur has been successfully filled into the NOPC-600 porous carbon matrix via the capillary force. Fig. 3(c) presents the EDS mapping images of the S/NOPC-600. It can be seen that carbon and sulfur are homogeneously dispersed in the S/NOPC-600 (Fig. 3c1 and c5), implying that sulfur is well-confined within the NOPC-600 porous host. Furthermore, the elementals of N, O and P can be also detected in the sulfur/carbon composite (Fig. 3c2–c4), which is consistent with the XPS analysis in Fig. 5(a). The XRD patterns of the obtained NOPC and S/NOPC are shown in Fig. 4 (a). For the three pure porous carbon materials (NOPC-550, NOPC-600 and NOPC-650), a broad characteristic diffraction peak can be found at 20°−30°, which is ascribed to an amorphous structure of carbon framework. Meanwhile, other weak peaks are also observed in these carbon materials, which may be related to the formation of phosphates in high temperature carbonization process [52,53]. After loading sulfur into the carbon matrix, strong and sharp characteristic peaks appear in the S/NOPC composites, which corresponds to the typical XRD patterns of crystalline sublimated sulfur with orthorhombic structure (S8, JCPDS#08-0247) [27,36]. These results indicate that sulfur is well combined with carbon substrate and exists in a crystal state in the S/NOPC composites. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted under a nitrogen atmosphere to probe the sulfur content in the S/NOPC-550, S/NOPC-600 and S/NOPC-650 composites. As displayed in Fig. 4(b), the noticeable mass losses of the three composites take place between ∼175 °C and 400 °C, which are referred to the evaporation of sulfur at high temperature. The sulfur contents of S/NOPC-550, S/NOPC-600 and S/NOPC-650 are 51.98 wt%, 54.33 wt% and 50.92 wt%, respectively. The TGA curve of S/NOPC-550 shows a steep slope, suggesting a rapid weight loss of sulfur. As presented in SEM results, the NOPC-550 possesses a slightly tight structure and little porosity so that the sulfur cannot be completely embedded into its porosities and/or nanopores. Compared with S/NOPC-550, S/NOPC-600 has a higher weight loss (54.33 wt%) at high temperature, which may be attributed to its loose and abundant porous structure that can effectively pack sulfur by physical adsorption and accommodate enough sulfur. Among these composites, the smallest sulfur content is detected in the S/NOPC-650, which is related to its dense and hardened structure with few pores or porosities. The BET measurement is an effective technology for researching the porous structure of carbon materials. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves of the prepared NOPC materials are illustrated in Fig. 4(c, d), respectively. From Fig. 4(c), the NOPC-600 shows a type IV isotherm profile at a relative low pressure region of P/P 0  < 1 on the basis of IUPAC classification, indicating a strong nitrogen adsorption and the presence of hierarchical pores in the carbon structure [34–36]. The calculated Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area for the NOPC-600 is 535.352 cm2 g−1. It can be found that the surface areas of the NOPC-550 and NOPC-650 are much smaller than that of the NOPC-600, giving the values of 60.454 and 52.933 cm2 g−1, respectively, which should be ascribed to their dense microstructure with low porosity. Based on density functional theory (DFT) analysis, the pore size distributions and pore volumes of the NOPC materials can be calculated and the results are shown in Fig. 4(d). It can be noted that many micropores and mesopores exist in the NOPC materials and the range for main pore size distribution is from 0.6 nm to 7.0 nm. The NOPC-600 has the largest pore volume of 0.388 cm3 g−1, and the average pore size is around 2.63 nm. However, the NOPC-550 and NOPC-650 exhibit much smaller pore volumes than the NOPC-650, giving the values of 0.093 and 0.041 cm3 g−1, respectively, suggesting the weak interaction of the NOPC-550 and NOPC-650 materials with N2. In addition, NOPC-550 and NOPC-650 possess a slightly larger pore size distribution than NOPC-600, which is not conducive to packaging sulfur and anchoring polysulfides. The corresponding textural properties of the materials are summarized in Table 1 . The NOPC-600 exhibits much larger specific surface area and pore volume, and smaller average pore diameter than the NOPC-550 and NOPC-650. The developed small-sized mesopores structure and large pore volume have greater ability in restraining the long-chain polysulfides dissolution and cushioning volume expansion during the charge/discharge process of Li–S batteries via the strong capillary force. These imply that the NOPC-600 may be an excellent host material to optimize the electrochemical performance [25,44,45]. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra of the S/NOPC-600 are shown in Fig. 5. From Fig. 5(a), five peaks can be clearly observed at 291.1, 406.7, 537.9, 140.9 and 171.6 eV in the wide-survey XPS spectrum, corresponding to C 1s, N 1s, O 1s, P 2p and S 2p, respectively. Clearly, the material consists of C, N, O, P and S elements. And the contents of these elements (C, N, O, P and S) on the S/NOPC-600 surface are 73.74 at%, 3.70 at%, 5.69 at%, 3.37 at% and 13.50 at%, respectively. This proves that N, O and P tri-doped carbon has been successfully synthesized in this work. The high-resolution C 1s, N 1s, O 1s, P 2p and S 2p spectra for the S/NOPC-600 are depicted in Fig. 5(b-f), respectively. The C 1s spectrum in Fig. 5(b) is decomposed into four peaks which represent CC/CC at 283.2 eV, CO/CN at 283.8 eV, CO at 285.9 eV and OCO at 289.5 eV [54], respectively. Obviously, the S/NOPC-600 contains many heteroatom functional groups on carbon the surface, which is conducive to enhancing the ability of immobilizing long-chain lithium polysulfides depended on the chemical adsorption [35,36,39]. From the N 1s spectrum in Fig. 5(c), four different chemical environments of nitrogen are exhibited, which are attributed to pyridinic N at 397.1 eV, pyrrolic N at 398.9 eV, graphitic N at 400.3 eV and quaternary N at 401.3 eV, respectively. These N species can offer stable active sites and facilitate the formation of chemical bonds between sulfur atoms and oxygen functional groups [34–36]. Furthermore, the pyridinic N and pyrrolic N based on the lone-pair electrons can generate the strong chemical interaction with polysulfides species on the porous carbon surface [54,55]. These are beneficial to improve the utilization of sulfur and the anchoring ability to long chain polysulfides. The O 1s spectrum in Fig. 5(d) shows four peaks, corresponding to CO (carboyl) groups at 530.2 eV, CO (ester, amides) groups at 531.5 eV, COC groups at 533.6 eV and COH/NOC at 535.1 eV [36,54,55], respectively, which confirm the existence of oxygen-containing groups in the prepared goat hair-derived carbon framework. Oxygen functional groups can react with polysulfides to form stable Li–O bonds because of the strong electronegative nature of O and thus weaken the dissolution of polysulfides [54]. From Fig. 5(e), the main peak of P 2p is divided into three distinct peaks, which may be assigned to phosphate at 132.1 eV, pyrophosphate at 132.8 eV and metaphosphate at 134.1 eV [52,53,56], respectively. Different types of P–S bonds can be formed between these phosphorus-oxygen functional groups and polysulfides, which reduce the dissolving of intermediates into electrolyte during charge/discharge process [37]. The S 2p spectrum in Fig. 5(f) can be divided into four peaks, representing the S 2p 3/2 and S 2p 1/2 components at 162.4 and 163.6 eV, and sulfate species at 167.1 and 168.4 eV, respectively. The S 2p 3/2 and S 2p 1/2 may be related to the S–S bonds, while sulfate species should result from the strong reaction of sulfur and oxygen [57]. The contents of all elements in the S/NOPC-600 and the corresponding component analysis are listed Table 2 . All these characteristics show that N, O and P heteroatoms have been successfully introduced into the carbon materials and are favor of enhancing the affinity between polar polysulfides and nonpolar carbon frameworks. Therefore, it can be reasonably expected that N, O and P tri-doped porous carbon host material can effectively suppress the shuttle effect and improve the electrical stability of the Li–S batteries during cycling. The initial charge/discharge profiles of the S/NOPC-500, S/NOPC-600 and S/NOPC-650 at 0.2 C are presented in Fig. 6 (a). All three cathodes possess two typical discharge platforms at ∼2.30 and 2.05 V and one long charge platforms at 2.21–2.48 V, which are in coincidence with the solid–liquid–solid reaction mechanism of Li–S batteries [58]. Compared with the S/NOPC-550 and S/NOPC-650 electrodes, S/NOPC-600 electrode shows the highest discharge capacity of 921 mA h g−1, which manifests the optimum utilization of sulfur in the S/NOPC-600 electrode. This is closely related to the microstructures of the materials. Fig. 6(b) displays the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of the S/NOPC-600 electrode for the first three cycles at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1 between 1.5 and 3.0 V. Two reduction peaks of the cathode can be observed at ∼2.30 V and 2.05 V, which correspond to two processes of the reduction of sulfur to long-chain dissolved polysulfides and further conversion of soluble polysulfides to insoluble Li2S2 and Li2S. One oxidation peak was also found at ∼ 2.46 V, which allocate to the oxidation processes of Li2S2/Li2S to long-chain lithium polysulfides/sulfur [5–7]. All peaks of these CV curves are well matched with each other, demonstrating the high-degree reversibility and superior electrochemical stability of the S/NOPC-600 cathode. The selected charge/discharge profiles (1st, 2nd, 10th, 20th, 50th, 100th, 200th and 300th) of the S/NOPC-600 cathode at 0.2 C (1 C1675 mA g−1) from 1.7 V to 3.0 V are presented in Fig. 6(c). All discharge profiles have two obvious voltage platforms at ∼2.30 and ∼2.05 V, corresponding to the two processes of the reductions: sulfur to high-order polysulfides (Li2S x , 4 ≤ x ≤ 8) at the high platform and Li2S x (4 ≤ x ≤ 8) to final low-order polysulfides (Li2S/Li2S2) at the low platform [39,44]. All charge profiles have one long platform at 2.21–2.50 V, which can be assigned to the reverse reaction of Li2S2/Li2S to lithium polysulfides and sulfur. The results agree well with the CV exam of the S/NOPC-600 cathode. Fig. 6(d) displays the galvanostatic charge/discharge profiles of the S/NOPC-600 cathode at various current densities (from 0.05 C to 2 C). The discharge capacities of 1185 mA h g−1, 1064 mA h g−1, 921 mA h g−1, 810 mA h g−1, 537 mA h g−1 and 355 mA h g−1 are obtained at 0.05 C, 0.1 C, 0.2 C, 0.5 C, 1 C and 2 C, respectively. Furthermore, the typical charge/discharge platforms in these curves can be clearly observed even at high current densities, which indicate the high utilization of sulfur and good stability of the S/NOPC-600 cathode. Fig. 6(e) displays the rate performance of the S/NOPC-600 cathode. Apparently, a reversible capacity of 600 mA h g−1 can be recovered when the current density returns to 0.2 C, indicating that the electrode has the excellent rate capability and redox reversibility [59]. Energy efficiency and coulombic efficiency of the S/NOPC-600 from the tenth charge/discharge curves at different densities are depicted in Fig. 6(f). The S/NOPC-600 cathode shows high coulombic efficiencies of ∼99% from 0.05 C to 0.5 C and ∼96% from 1 C to 2 C, which indicate an infirm shuttle effect and a high utilization of active sulfur. Meanwhile, the S/NOPC-600 cathode displays high energy efficiencies of 93.90%, 93.01%, 90.92%, 89.38%, 87.25% and 72.00% at rates of 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1 and 2 C, respectively, which reveal an excellent utilization of energy in the cell. The improved electrochemical performance of the S/NOPC-600 cathode should be attributed to the synergistic effect of the special physical structure and inherent tri-doping of N, O and P of NOPC-600. To further prove the potential advantages of the material as cathode host material of Li–S batteries, the long-term cycling characteristics of the S/NOPC-550, S/NOPC-600 and S/NOPC-650 electrodes are evaluated at 0.2 C between 1.7 and 3.0 V. As illustrated in Fig. 6(g), the S/NOPC-600 composite delivers a high initial discharge capacity of 921 mA h g−1 and retains a capacity of 489 mA h g−1 (capacity retention: 53.09%) with an average coulombic efficiency of 98% after 300 cycles. However, the S/NOPC-550 and S/NOPC-650 electrodes display much lower initial discharge capacity of 833 mA h g−1 and 517.8 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C than the S/NOPC-600; in addition, compared with the S/NOPC-600, the two electrodes exhibit much smaller discharge specific capacities of 363.2 mA h g−1 and 359.8 mA h g−1 with lower coulombic efficiency of 96% after 300 cycles. Obviously, the S/NOPC-600 has a better cycle stability than other samples in the long-term cycling measurement, which is closely related to the microcosmic characteristics of NOPC-600. Evidently, the high specific surface area, cauliflower-like hierarchical porous structure and appropriate pore size of the NOPC-600 can not only promote encapsulation of sulfur, but also restrict the dissolution of polysulfides in liquid electrolyte and alleviate volume change of the materials during reaction process, which is beneficial to restraining the “shuttle effect” of Li–S batteries [44]. As a result, a good cycle stability is obtained in the S/NOPC-600 composite. Table 3 shows electrochemical performance of some reported biomass-derived carbon/sulfur composites for Li–S batteries. Compared with these reports, the S/NOPC-600 shows relatively excellent discharge capacity and cycle stability. To prove the ions and electrons transfer performance of the materials, the cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements have been carried out at different scanning rates varying from 0.1 to 0.5 mV s−1 and the results are illustrated in Fig. 7 . All cathodic and anodic peak currents show a linear relationship to the square root of scan rates (Fig. 7(a–c)). The A peak represents the oxidation reaction of Li2S2/Li2S to long-chain lithium polysulfides/sulfur [6]. The B and C peaks stand for two reduction reaction of sulfur to long-chain dissolved polysulfides and soluble polysulfides to insoluble Li2S2 and Li2S [6]. The Li+ diffusion coefficients of the three S/NOPC cathodes can be calculated from the classical Randles–Sevcik equation as follows [66]: (1) I p = 2.687 × 10 5 n 1.5 A D Li + 0.5 v 0.5 C Li where I p represents the peak current, n is the number of electrons in the reaction (n = 2), A stands for the effective electrode area (1.53 cm2), D Li+ is the Li+ diffusion coefficient, v is the scanning rate (0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4 and 0.5 mV s−1) and C Li refers to the Li+ concentration in the electrolyte. The slopes of curves in Fig. 7(d) are positively correlated to the corresponding Li+ diffusion. Evidently, the A2, B2 and C2 curves exhibit the largest slope among A1, A2 and A3, B1, B2 and B3, and C1, C2 and C3, suggesting that the S/NOPC-600 cathode possesses the fastest Li+ diffusion velocity, compared with the S/NOPC-550 and S/NOPC-650. During the charging/discharging process, ions and electrons will interact, resulting in the redox reaction [5], which implies that the S/NOPC-600 also has excellent electron transfer performance. The hierarchical porous structure of the S/NOPC-600 can provide abundant electrons and ions transmission channels and thus leads to good ions and electrons transfer performance. The enhancement in the electrochemical performance for the S/NOPC-600 electrode is mainly attributed to the synergetic effect of the doping of inherent heteroatoms and unique physical structure of the host material (NOPC-600). On the one hand, as illustrated in Fig. 5 and Table 2, the NOPC-600 contains abundant intrinsic heteroatoms and various functional groups. These in-situ N, O and P heteroatoms can significantly suppress the shuttle effect of Li–S batteries, because the strong chemical interaction induced by heteroatoms restrains the dissolution of long-chain intermediates into organic electrolyte during the cycling. On the other hand, the cauliflower-like hierarchical porous structure with high specific surface area and abundant micropores and small-sized mesopores not only serves as large reservoir to load enough sulfur and effectively anchors the polysulfides, but also offers rapid transmission channels for electrons and ions and alleviates volume change during charging/discharging. These are in favor of enhancing electrochemical performance of the S/NOPC-600 electrode. Fig. 8 (a, b) exhibits the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) spectra of the three S/NOPC cathodes before discharge and after 30 cycles, respectively. From Fig. 8(a), the Nyquist plots for the three S/NOPC cathodes before discharge are composed of a semicircle in the high to medium frequency region and an oblique straight line at low frequency. The semicircle assigns to the interface charge-transfer resistance (R ct) at the interface between the electrolyte and sulfur electrode. The inclined line corresponds to the lithium ions diffusion resistance (Warburg impedance) of the electrode [67]. Apparently, the S/NOPC-600 exhibits a smallest resistance among all S/NOPC cathodes. This reason is that the S/NOPC-600 has higher surface area and more hierarchical pores than the S/NOPC-550 and S/NOPC-650, which is in favor of accelerating the surface charge transfer and lithium ions diffusion in the electrode by providing enough pathways and increasing contact between the insulating sulfur and conductive carbon [44,45]. As presented in Fig. 8(b), after 30 cycles, it can be found that the impedance spectra of the three cathodes still consist of a semicircle in high to middle frequency region and an oblique line in the low frequency region, demonstrating that the impedance behaviors are similar to those before discharge. However, it is expressly observed that the overall impedance increases after 30 cycles. Typically, this phenomenon is related to the deposition of insulating Li2S/Li2S2 on the surface of the electrode and the higher viscosity of electrolyte and lower Li+ ion mobility owing to the dissolution of some long-chain polysulfides into the electrolyte after cycling [68]. Obviously, the S/NOPC-600 cathode still exhibits the smallest electrochemical resistance among the three electrodes after 30 charge/discharge cycles, which suggests that the S/NOPC-600 possesses an excellent electrochemical reaction kinetics process, leading to the best electrochemical performance among the three samples. The excellent electrochemical properties of the S/NOPC-600 composite can be ascribed to the synergetic effect of the doping of inherent heteroatoms and unique cauliflower-like hierarchical porous physical structure of the host material (NOPC-600). 4 Conclusions An in-situ N, O and P tri-doped cauliflower-like hierarchical porous carbon has been successfully synthesized via a facile method of H3PO4 activation and high-temperature carbonization using low-cost, naturally abundant and easily available goat hair as carbon source. The obtained NOPC-600 material exhibits hierarchical porous structure and can be employed as excellent conductive matrix for Li–S batteries. Owing to the synergistic effect of the unique physical structure and inherent N, O and P tri-doping, the OPNC-600 carbon material can provide rich rapid transportation pathways for electrons and ions, enhance the utilization of active sulfur and effectively restrain the shuttle behaviors of long-chain polysulfides. As a result, the S/NOPC-600 cathode delivers a high initial discharge capacity of 1185 mA h g−1 at 0.05 C and maintains a reversible capacity of 489 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C after 300 cycles. Our study presents an eco-friendly and low-cost strategy to synthesize hierarchical porous carbons for high performance of Li–S batteries using natural biomass as precursor. coredata.dc:description: Biomass-derived carbon materials have aroused widespread concern as host material of sulfur to enhance electrochemical performances for lithium–sulfur batteries. Herein, goat hair, as a low-cost and eco-friendly precursor, is employed to fabricate cauliflower-like in-situ nitrogen, oxygen and phosphorus tri-doped porous biomass carbon (NOPC) by a facile activation with H3PO4 and carbonization process. The morphology and microstructure of NOPC can be readily tuned by altering pyrolysis temperature. The as-prepared NOPC matrix material carbonized at 600 °C possesses 3D hierarchical porous structure, high specific surface area (535.352 m2 g−1), and appropriate pore size and pore size distribution. Encapsulating sulfur into the NOPC depends on a stem-melting technology as cathode materials of Li–S batteries. Due to the synergistic effect of special physical structure and inherent tri-doping of N, O and P, electrons and ions transfer and utilization of active sulfur in the materials are improved, and the shuttle behaviors of soluble lithium polysulfides are also mitigated. Consequently, the S/NOPC-600 composite exhibits excellent electrochemical performance, giving a high initial discharge capacity of 1185 mA h g−1 at 0.05 C and maintaining a relatively considerable capacity of 489 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C after 300 cycles. Our work shows that a promising candidate for cathode material of Li–S batteries can be synthesized using low-cost and renewable biomass materials by a facile process.

coredata.dc:title: Sulfur-encapsulated in heteroatom-doped hierarchical porous carbon derived from goat hair for high performance lithium–sulfur batteries
